awd_titl_txt: RUI: Investigations of hydrogels formed by semenogelin I-derived peptide sequences
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrogels are materials with a tremendous capacity to absorb water, which makes them useful for a variety of every-day applications such as baby diapers, contact lenses and drug encapsulation.  Hydrogels consist of polymer networks and new types of hydrogel polymers are continuously being developed.  There is a considerable interest in learning what the detailed structure of a hydrogel looks like and how the structure of the network influences the hydrogel properties as well as how the hydrogel polymers can be modified at will. The aim of this research is to investigate the formation of a hydrogel from natural proteins.  This hydrogel, because it is of natural origin, is non-toxic, biocompatible, biodegradable and environmentally friendly.  This research involves an international collaboration between research groups at Haverford College, US; Lund University, Sweden; and the University of Cambridge, UK.  The project provides interdisciplinary and international research opportunities to undergraduate students.  The project also includes participation by  students from underrepresented groups, preparing them for graduate studies in a variety of chemically related fields, as well as for careers in industry.  The undergraduate participants of this project gain direct hands-on experience and training in state-of-the-art methodologies for solid-phase protein synthesis and purification.  

This research aims to understand gel formation by peptide scaffolds.  The oligopeptide under investigation self-assembles to form fibrils consisting of extended beta-sheets.  This short 10-residue peptide forms a hydrogel with properties that are particularly well suited for systematic investigations.  This project probes the sequence-specific determinants of hydrogel formation by studying a series of mutants and truncated versions of the oligopeptide, employing predominantly circular dichroism and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy for their characterization  The research interrogates the self-assembly process by incorporating isotopically labeled residues into the sequence.  Finally, the researchers follow the kinetics of fibril formation using a thioflavine-based assay, which is also used as a tool to assess the effects of external variables, such as pH, on aggregation.

por.por_cntn:
Background. This project is an international collaboration between Haverford College, PA, an undergraduate liberal arts college, and research groups at graduate institutions in Sweden (Lund U), Israel (Weizmann Institute), Italy (U of Calabria), and the UK (Cambridge).

Peptide-based hydrogels of natural origin are of particular interest in medical applications as they are non-toxic and compatible with a biological environment. Our target of choice is a short sequence that resides within a naturally occurring protein, semenogelin I, the main constituent in seminal plasma, and that forms a gel-like substance similar in properties to the full-length protein. The 13-residue peptide self-assembles under physiological conditions to generate a cross-linked polymer network capable of sequestering copious amounts of water.  It is referred to as a smart hydrogel as it gelates under certain conditions, in response to an environmental cue, such as a change in pH or the addition of a specific metal ion. Our goals have been to learn about the chemical principles and detailed molecular interactions of this system that lead to gelation as well as decipher the mechanistic details of peptide self-assembly and fibrillation that ultimately leads to a hydrogel.

Results. At acidic pH, the peptide is charged and unable to self-assemble to form a hydrogel network. A pH-adjustment to neutral (7-9), which removes the repelling charges, functions as a switch to trigger hydrogelation and is consistent with the deprotonation of a histidine residue. A new, Raman spectroscopy-based, method was developed in order to determine the exact pKa of this histidine residue, which was not tractable by more traditional means, including NMR spectroscopy. Histidine has a physiologically relevant pKa, and its exact value, which is dependent on nearby amino acid residues, is often of interest in order to more fully understand the behavior of a particular system. The method described in this project is also well suited for determining the pKa of this residue in peptides that are hydrophobic and active in a membrane environment, as well as for the determination of the pKa of one histidine in the presence of others, as the method uses a deuterium-probe that can be incorporated selectively into the histidine of interest.  

We have also determined the detailed step-by-step mechanism of the fibrils produced by the SgI 37-49 peptide. This work led to the most detailed mechanistic study of a hydrogel-forming peptide system published to date.

A systematic investigation has been carried out of a series of truncated peptides related to original peptide, in which the amino acid residue was removed, one-by-one, from one end to furnish a series of peptides comprising between 3-13 residues. A correlation was made between the secondary structure of each peptide, generated by FTIR spectroscopy, and its materials properties, which were compiled using rheology, SAXS/WAX and cryo-TEM.

Vibrational-sensitive probes (a 13C or a nitrile, CN) were judiciously incorporated into select positions of the original peptide sequence, and were used to report on the orientation between strands within the β-sheet layers of the fibrils, which can be either parallel or antiparallel, as well as to determine the degree of interactions between strands and how water-exposed they are within the sequence in the hydrogel state. The structural picture that emerges from our investigations strongly suggest that the 13-residue peptide self-assembles to generate a double layer of β-sheets in which the strands within each layer are perpendicular to the fibril axis. The strands are amphiphilic in nature in which the self-assembly process is driven by embedding the hydrophobic face of each strand toward the interior of the double β-sheet layer. Within each layer, the strands are antiparallel. In addition, the ends of the strands are more loosely hydrogen-bonded compared to at the center, leading to frayed ends.

Outcomes. Fifteen undergraduate students (identified as 8 female, 7 male) have been engaged in this project for 1-3 years. Five students travelled with the PI to Lund U, Sweden, to conduct research. Two obtained Fulbright research scholarships to work in chemistry, at Lund U. Currently, all students are pursuing higher education at first-rate institutions, with 5 in graduate school in chemistry/engineering (one in Denmark, one in the UK), three in medical school, and one in veterinary school. The rest are now gaining additional research/work-related experiences before heading to medical school (3), or graduate school in business (2).  During this time, four articles have been published in major peer-reviewed journals, with one additional manuscript in preparation, and with 13 undergraduate co-authors, including 5 who conducted the preliminary investigations that led up to this award. The PI was a guest professor at Lund U, where she organized two conferences. She was also given an Honorary Doctorate from Lund University for her commitment to undergraduate education and involving undergraduates in significant research projects.
